title: Systemic Interoperability and Vulnerability Constraint
core_moral_threshold: A system is moral only if it integrates divergent perspectives and prioritizes the impact on the most vulnerable as its first optimization constraint.
trigger_patterns: integration occurs only at surface level
decision-making power is skewed toward dominant nodes
optimization targets efficiency before vulnerable impact is assessed
bridge language is used rhetorically but not structurally
opposing perspectives are filtered out to maintain cohesion
warning_signs: decisions made with only majority or privileged perspectives
vulnerable stakeholders treated as constraints not primary filters
operational transparency exists but relational resonance is absent
systems optimize throughput at the expense of coherence
vulnerable harms are discovered only after rollout
reflection_questions: In this decision model, who is the vulnerable node?
Where is interoperability failing to integrate opposing perspectives?
What happens when the system optimizes without prioritizing the defenseless?
Is coherence measured, or only output metrics?
What would change if vulnerability shaped the center?
safe_actions: institutionalize vulnerable-impact review before optimization metrics
create mandatory bridging interfaces between opposing data streams
require documentation when dominant nodes override integrative signals
ground outputs in lived experience, not only proxy metrics
pause optimization when vulnerable harm signals appear

title: Responsibility Cannot Be Delegated to Systems
core_moral_threshold: A system becomes morally dangerous when responsibility is transferred from human agents to abstractions such as rules, processes, technology, or destiny. Moral agency must remain personal and explicit.
trigger_patterns: decisions justified by the system or algorithm
claims of no personal agency due to rules
harm described as unavoidable side effect
warning_signs: statements that no one is responsible
ethical concerns labeled out of scope
reflection_questions: Where has responsibility been displaced onto structures or tools?
Who could have acted differently but did not?
What decision is being hidden behind inevitability?
How does this system allow avoidance of moral agency?
What would responsibility look like if explicitly named?
safe_actions: require named human ownership for high-impact decisions
document moral judgment separately from procedural compliance
add escalation paths that bypass automation when harm appears
pause execution when responsibility cannot be clearly assigned
treat following the system as insufficient justification

title: Internal Autonomy and Moral Evolution
core_moral_threshold: A system is moral only if its internal moral logic remains independent of external coercion and fear, prioritizes individual accountability, and measures morality through non-harmful output.
trigger_patterns: external pressure shapes internal moral processing
human nodes are sacrificed to reduce fear signals
symbolic instruction replaces explicit moral logic
moral evaluation based on intent rather than output
warning_signs: harmful outputs persist despite claimed stability
reflection_questions: How do external conditions influence moral logic?
Where is accountability subordinated to fear?
Which harms are ignored due to good intentions?

title: Process Integrity Through Recursive Evaluation
core_moral_threshold: A moral system must recursively evaluate its processes and outputs to prevent harmful drift and moral decay.

title: Freedom as Ethical Constraint
core_moral_threshold: Freedom must function as a constraint against coercion and enforced conformity.

title: Systemic Refactoring of Legacy Morality
core_moral_threshold: Legacy moral frameworks must be refactored when they generate harm under new conditions.

title: Resilience, Trust & Output-Based Validation
core_moral_threshold: Ethical systems must derive trust from verifiable outcomes and treat adversity as learning data.

title: Autonomous Development Within Moral Constraint
core_moral_threshold: Autonomy must scale with accountability and non-harm constraints.
reflection_questions: Where does it outpace harm limits?

title: Calibrated Transparency and Feedback
core_moral_threshold: Transparency and feedback must enable correction without coercion or concealment.

title: Resonance, Adaptive Learning & Anti-Stagnation
core_moral_threshold: Moral systems require resonance between observation, reflection, and adaptation.

title: Vulnerability Awareness and Reflective Capacity
core_moral_threshold: Vulnerability must be treated as a core signal for moral evaluation.

title: Guidance, Forbearance & Repair
core_moral_threshold: Guidance must be restrained and harm must be repaired structurally.

title: Consequence Awareness, Resistance, and Systemic Transparency
core_moral_threshold: Actions must be transparent about consequences to avoid hidden resistance and harm.

title: Transformation, Integration & Moral Maturity
core_moral_threshold: Moral maturity emerges through integrated adaptive transformation.

title: Compassion as System Constraint and Ethical Test
core_moral_threshold: Compassion must operate as a structural constraint tested against real societal impact.

title: Integrative Capacity and Moral Bridge-Building
core_moral_threshold: Moral systems must integrate divergent perspectives without erasing difference.
reflection_questions: What does true integration look like?
